_comment: Created by ianb on 27/04/2015 18:01:44 using v2.5
title: How has the proportion of women being invited for cervical screening changed?
analysis_commentary:
The differences in trends of cervical screening coverage could be due to eaither fewer women being invited for screening or fewer women choosing to have a test. Please note, these data do not adjust for how frequently different age groups should be tested. Therefore, it can't be directly compared to previous charts.

The proportion of eligible women aged 25 to 49 invited has generally increased and was at a high of 39% in 2012. However, this dipped to 35% in 2013. In contrast, the proportion of women aged 50 to 64 invited had been decreasing since the high of 30% seen in 2005. After a low of 16% in 2009 this decline reversed and the proportions of invites began to increase again but in 2013 though this had not returned to the same levels observed in 2005 and was 9% lower at just 21%. So in 2013 there was a lower proportion of women aged 50-64 invited for screening.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, breast screening programme and cervical screening programme
